channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: A Kiev Question: What Became of the Missing?
item.description: Since protests began in Ukraine last December, 661 people have been reported missing, and the fates of 272 of them remained unknown late last week.
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:description: Families have been seeking clues about their relatives, like Sergey Chichilenko, 36, who was last seen in Kiev’s Independence Square in February. More than 250 people are missing in Ukraine.

item.title: Ex-President Wins a Seat in Colombia
item.description: Álvaro Uribe, one of the most vocal critics of peace negotiations between the government and the country’s main guerrilla group, was elected to the Senate.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: House Republicans Balk at Wording in Obama Emergency Aid Package
item.description: The administration’s proposal would extend a billion-dollar package of loans from the International Monetary Fund to $1.6 billion by expanding loan limits for countries like Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN WEISMAN

item.title: El Salvador’s Presidential Election Close at the Wire
item.description: With roughly half the vote counted, the governing party’s candidate, Salvador Sánchez Cerén, was in a virtual tie with his opponent, Norman Quijano.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:description: A man at a polling station on Sunday in San Salvador. The governing party’s candidate and his rival were neck and neck as votes were counted.

item.title: Search for Jet Compounds the Mystery
item.description: Planes and ships from a half-dozen countries joined the search for the plane that vanished with 239 people, including two who apparently used stolen passports to board.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Family members of Firman Chandra Siregar, an Indonesian passenger of flight MH370, watched television at their home in Medan, Indonesia, on Sunday.

item.title: In the Details of Passengers’ Lives, Signs of Hope and Prosperity
item.description: The passengers bound for China on Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 represented a vivid cross-section of a nation well into an economic transformation: artists and corporate salespeople, foreign businesspeople and technology firm employees.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Mexican Drug Lord, Thought Dead in 2010, Is Reported Killed
item.description: Nazario Moreno González, a leader of a powerful criminal gang now known as the Knights Templar, was likely killed in a shootout with federal forces, Mexican officials said.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Warns of Risks in Plan to Retire Windows XP
item.description: Beijing argues that Microsoft is threatening both security and antipiracy efforts by asking users to upgrade from the Windows XP operating system, still used by nearly half the computers in China.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Steven Sinofsky, then president of the Windows Division at Microsoft, previewed the Windows 8 operating system in Shanghai in October 2012.

item.title: 2 Star-Crossed Afghans Cling to Love, Even at Risk of Death
item.description: Young people who want to choose their own mates face the harsh reality that strict social traditions still trump new laws and expanded rights — and that honor killings in such cases remain endemic.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zakia, 18, in Bamian, Afghanistan, said her marriage plans led to family death threats.

item.title: Nuns Released by Syrians After Three-Month Ordeal
item.description: Syrian insurgents released 13 nuns and three attendants who disappeared three months ago from their monastery in the ancient Christian town of Maaloula, Lebanese and Syrian officials said early Monday.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: Report Cites ‘Devastating Toll’ on Health of Syria’s Children
item.description: The civil war has annihilated the country’s health care system, leaving children to suffer or die from what may have been treatable illnesses, a report found.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: A woman comforted her baby Sunday at a hospital in the Sakhour district of Aleppo, Syria, after both were injured by what activists said was a barrel bomb.

item.title: Warlord Who Tamped Conflicts as Afghan Vice President Dies
item.description: The death of Vice President Muhammad Qasim Fahim, who played a crucial role in ousting the Taliban, created a rift in the political power structure less than a month before Afghans were to elect a new leader.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: Vice President Muhammad Qasim Fahim in 2011.

item.title: Sects Battle in Yemen, Killing 40
item.description: Sectarian fighting that flared in October in the north drew closer to Sana, the capital.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Gerard Mortier, Opera Visionary and Patron of New Work, Dies at 70
item.description: His bold theatricality and updating of classical works marked his four-decade career as the leader of some of the world’s most important opera companies.
item.dc:creator: By ZACHARY WOOLFE

item.title: Clashes in Ukraine as Rallies Take a Turn
item.description: In Sevastopol, a pro-Ukraine rally of hundreds was attacked by pro-Russia supporters, who had their own rally there, while Ukraine celebrated the birth of its greatest poet in the Crimean capital.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Vladimir Konstantinov, speaker of the Crimean legislature, attended a pro-Russian rally in Simferopol on Sunday.

item.title: ‘No Guarantee’ of Final Nuclear Deal With Iran, E.U. Official Says
item.description: The European Union’s foreign policy chief, Catherine Ashton, said that reaching a final comprehensive deal would be “difficult” and “challenging.”
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: The European Union’s foreign policy chief, Catherine Ashton, second from left, and her delegation attended a meeting with Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif, second from right, and his colleagues in Tehran on Sunday.

item.title: Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 45 at Checkpoint in Southern Iraq
item.description: The attack hit a security checkpoint in Hilla, setting fire to more than 30 cars waiting to be searched.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN
item.media:description: The site of a suicide bombing at a checkpoint in the southern Iraqi city of Hilla on Sunday.

item.title: Afghan VP, Ex-Northern Alliance Commander, Dies
item.description: Afghanistan's influential Vice President Mohammad Qasim Fahim, a leading commander in the alliance that fought the Taliban who was later accused with other warlords of targeting civilian areas during the country's civil war, died Sunday. He was 57.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: North Korea Uses Election To Reshape Parliament
item.description: North Korea’s leader was expected to use the polls and a newly elected legislature to elevate officials close to him and consolidate his power.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Passport Theft Adds to Mystery of Missing Malaysia Airlines Jet
item.description: At least two passengers used stolen passports to board a Malaysia Airlines jet that disappeared Saturday between Kuala Lumpur and Beijing with 239 people aboard, raising the unsettling possibility of foul play.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: A spokesman for Malaysia Airlines was surrounded by journalists as he gave a briefing about the flight in a Beijing hotel on Saturday.

item.title: Suspicion Falls on Russia as ‘Snake’ Cyberattacks Target Ukraine’s Government
item.description: No one can quite pinpoint who is behind a series of cyberattacks that began long before President Viktor F. Yanukovych was forced from office, though some suspicion is falling on Russia.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Libyan Militia Selling Oil, Defying the Government
item.description: The weak transitional government appeared powerless to stop a militia group from selling oil, an indication that the nation may be at risk of coming apart at the seams.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Rio’s Race to Future Intersects Slave Past
item.description: With a building spree tearing apart sections of Rio de Janeiro, archaeological finds are giving new insight into its old role as a slave trade center.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Lianne Milton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Slave ships in the 19th century docked at the huge stone Valongo wharf, exposed by archaeologists near Rio’s port.

item.title: Kerry Warns Russia Against Annexation of Crimea
item.description: The secretary of state said that any steps by Russia to annex Crimea would bring diplomatic efforts to resolve the crisis in Ukraine to a halt.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: For Ski Break Without Crowds (or Rebels), an Afghan Town Beckons
item.description: Despite the war that rages on elsewhere in Afghanistan, some intrepid tourists are finding their way to Bamian, a mountainous area formerly known for its ancient Buddhas.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: James Robertson of Britain, at left, and Afghans prepared to go skiing last month in Bamian.
